mechanism: The caffeine intake stimulus is ingested and begins interacting with receptors and tissues in the mouth and stomach.
Components of the caffeine intake pass into the small intestine, where they are absorbed through the intestinal epithelium into the bloodstream.
The liver receives the absorbed molecules via the portal circulation and begins metabolizing them, shaping how strongly they can act on the body.
In key target organs, the main physiological effect occurs: Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, stimulating the central nervous system and increasing alertness.
The kidneys filter the blood, adjusting water and electrolyte excretion in response to the altered internal environment.
Multiple organ systems adapt together, integrating the stimulus into overall homeostasis.

Skeletal muscle fibers contract repeatedly, sharply increasing local ATP demand and heat production.
The heart increases rate and stroke volume to deliver more oxygenated blood to active muscles.
Breathing becomes deeper and faster, enhancing gas exchange to keep up with oxygen demand and CO2 removal.
Blood vessels in working muscles dilate while some others constrict, redistributing blood flow.
Hormonal and metabolic signals adjust fuel use and recovery; overall, Increases heart rate and aerobic endurance.
The brain monitors fatigue, coordination, and motivation, deciding whether to maintain or stop the activity.
